study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety of high-dose phytosterols in laying hens, specifically assessing potential toxicological effects.
results_summary: The study found no treatment-related changes of toxicological significance in laying hens fed phytosterol-supplemented diets, establishing 800 mg/kg as the no-observed-adverse-effect level. Clinical observations, laying performance, and postmortem examinations showed no adverse effects.
population_specificity: 21-week-old Hy-Line Brown laying hens

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of biological secondary wastewater treatment in removing phytosterols from pulp mill effluents to mitigate endocrine abnormalities in fish.
results_summary: Both bioreactor systems achieved high sterol removal (>90%), with biodegradation up to 80%. Reactor 1 performed better at lower pH (6.7) and specific retention times, while Reactor 2 (pH 7.6) showed poorer performance. Reduced retention times critically impacted biodegradation, but increased bio-adsorption maintained overall removal efficiency.
population_specificity: Pulp mill effluents (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Effluent sterols spiked up to 4500 μg/L.
study_duration: 11 h HRT and 11 day SRT for Reactor 1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of phytosterol and phytostanol (PS) supplementation on lipid profiles and apolipoproteins in adults through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials (RCTs).
results_summary: PS supplementation significantly reduced total cholesterol (TC), low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-c), and apolipoprotein B (Apo-B) levels, as well as Apo-B/apolipoprotein A1 ratios, while increasing high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels. The effects on TC, LDL-c, and Apo-B were dose-dependent.
population_specificity: Adults (1777 participants across 28 RCTs, including 895 cases and 882 controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the impact of phytosterol supplementation on serum lipid levels by conducting an umbrella review of interventional meta-analyses.
results_summary: The study synthesized existing meta-analyses to assess the effect of phytosterol supplementation on lipid profiles, using a random-effects model to compute overall effect sizes and confidence intervals. The abstract does not specify the direction or magnitude of the effects found.
population_specificity: Humans (specific subgroup not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: To evaluate the therapeutic benefits of nutraceuticals, including phytosterols, for migraine treatment through antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and gut microbiome-modulating effects.
results_summary: Phytosterols were found to suppress inflammation, potentially contributing to migraine relief. Nutraceuticals enriched in phytosterols and polyphenols showed promise in reducing oxidative stress and maintaining gut microbiota balance.
population_specificity: Not specified (general migraine pathology context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of phytosterol supplements on lipids, lipoprotein subfractions, and the quality of LDL particles in males with primary prevention of hypercholesterolemia.
results_summary: Phytosterol supplementation showed small beneficial effects on HDL-7 subfraction compared to diet alone but had no significant impact on LDL particle quality. It reduced total cholesterol, increased HDL-c, and reduced IDL-B, while diet alone increased HDL7 and reduced IDL-B.
population_specificity: 23 males in primary prevention of hypercholesterolemia.
study_duration: 12 weeks per intervention (24 weeks total with crossover).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current state of Phytosterols research, including their health benefits, applications, and unresolved gaps in understanding their mechanisms and chemical structures.
results_summary: The study highlights Phytosterols' beneficial effects in healthy subjects and their applications in food, cosmetics, and pharmaceuticals, but notes unresolved gaps in mechanisms, chemical characterization, and sustainability concerns.
population_specificity: Not specified (general healthy subjects and industrial applications)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review randomized clinical trials on the effects of phytosterol supplementation in capsules or tablets on lipid profiles and its use in treating hypercholesterolemia in adults.
results_summary: Most studies showed a positive association between phytosterol supplementation and cholesterol reduction, particularly in lowering LDL cholesterol, though interventions were short in duration. The review concluded that phytosterol supplements can help modulate lipid profiles but called for more research on these pharmaceutical formats.
population_specificity: Adult individuals with hypercholesterolemia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of phytosterols on lipid profiles in patients with hypercholesterolemia through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found that phytosterols significantly reduced total cholesterol (TC) and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) in patients with hypercholesterolemia, with statistically significant mean differences.
population_specificity: Patients with hypercholesterolemia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of phytosterol (PS) supplementation on lipid profiles in postmenopausal women through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: PS supplementation significantly reduced total cholesterol (TC) and LDL-C levels but had no effect on TG or HDL-C concentrations. Higher doses (≥2 g/day) and use in participants with BMI ≥25 kg/m² showed more notable reductions in TC and LDL-C.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a nutraceutical combination containing phytosterols, bergamot, olive fruits, and vitamin K on serum lipid profile and inflammatory parameters in individuals with hypercholesterolemia.
results_summary: The study found that the nutraceutical combination did not significantly reduce total cholesterol or alter serum lipid profile and inflammatory parameters at the daily dose applied over 6 and 12 weeks compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Individuals with hypercholesterolemia (specific details not provided).

study_goal: To systematically review the effects of phytosterol supplementation on dyslipidemia treatment in children and adolescents.
results_summary: Phytosterol supplementation reduced LDL-cholesterol levels by approximately 10%, with greater reductions observed after 8-12 weeks. No significant changes in HDL-cholesterol or triglyceride levels were found, and the intervention appeared safe and well-tolerated.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with dyslipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of phytosterol (PS) supplementation on serum lipoprotein(a) (Lp(a)) and free fatty acid (FFA) concentration through a systematic review and meta-analysis of available RCTs.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that oral PS supplementation significantly reduced serum Lp(a) and FFA levels, indicating a beneficial effect on these biomarkers.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a new phytosterol emulsion (1.5 g/day) on LDLc concentrations in healthy adults.
results_summary: Phytosterol supplementation significantly lowered LDLc concentrations by 10.2% (16.17 mg/dL or 0.419 mmol/L). Secondary endpoints related to cardiovascular health were also assessed.
population_specificity: Thirty-two healthy adults.
study_duration: One month per phase (crossover design with washout).

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of phytosterol capsule supplementation combined with the NCEP Step 2 diet on LDL-C levels in children and adolescents with dyslipidemia.
results_summary: Phytosterol supplementation did not significantly reduce LDL-C, TC, HDL-C, insulin, triglycerides, or blood pressure compared to the control group. High capsule adherence but low diet adherence may have influenced the results.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents (n=31, mean age 9.0 ± 2.22 years, BMI z-score 1.65 ± 1.47 kg/m²) with dyslipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically investigate the effectiveness of phytosterol and phytostanol supplementation on atherogenic and anti-atherogenic apolipoproteins in adults.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that phytosterol supplementation and fortification increased Apo-AI levels, with a weighted mean difference of 0.014 mg/dl (95% CI: 0.001, 0.028). The study included 51 arms from 37 randomized controlled trials.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of phytosterols and phytostanol supplementation on anthropometric indices, such as weight, through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 79 randomized controlled trials found no significant effect of phytosterol supplementation on weight, with a weighted mean difference of -0.083 kg and a confidence interval that included zero.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract (likely general adult population based on typical phytosterol studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether combining high-molecular-weight oat β-glucan (OBG) and phytosterols (PS) in a functional food could enhance their cholesterol-lowering effects in hypercholesterolaemic individuals.
results_summary: Phytosterols alone significantly reduced total cholesterol (TC) and LDL-C (-4.6% and -7.6%, respectively), while the combination with OBG led to greater reductions (-11.5% and -13.9%). The effects were additive, with no significant changes in HDL-C or triglycerides.
population_specificity: Hypercholesterolaemic individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of sterols/stanols as lipid-lowering agents, their influence on cardiovascular risk, and their safety.
results_summary: The study found that sterols and stanols effectively lower LDL-cholesterol levels and reduce cardiovascular risk, but some evidence suggests phytosterols may not benefit atherogenesis and could pose risks in individuals with high serum levels.
population_specificity: General population, with specific mention of patients with phytosterolaemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the lipid-lowering effects of phytosterols, their mechanisms of action, and potential applications in cardiovascular disease prevention.
results_summary: Phytosterols lower blood cholesterol by ~10% and may reduce triglycerides, particularly in hypertriglyceridemic subjects. They modulate lipid regulatory genes via LXR activation, but oxidized phytosterols in arterial lesions raise concerns about atherogenic potential.
population_specificity: Hypertriglyceridemic subjects and general populations with cholesterol concerns.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of adding phytosterols (PS) to high-intensity lipid-lowering therapies (LLT) on LDL cholesterol and markers of cholesterol synthesis and absorption.
results_summary: Adding PS to LLT further reduced total and LDL cholesterol (by ~7.7% and 6.5% with atorvastatin, 5.0% and 4.0% with combined therapy) but had no additional effects on cholesterol absorption or synthesis markers.
population_specificity: 86 patients of both genders with baseline atorvastatin 10 mg treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the bioavailability of CoQ₁₀ solubilized in low-dose soybean phytosterols (SterolQ₁₀) with a generic CoQ₁₀ solubilizate.
results_summary: The study found that SterolQ₁₀ and generic CoQ₁₀ were bioequivalent in terms of plasma CoQ₁₀ levels, with both formulations showing a comparable twofold increase after four weeks of supplementation.
population_specificity: 36 healthy males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of phytosterols and stanols on LDL-cholesterol reduction and their impact on surrogate markers of cardiovascular risk.
results_summary: Phytosterols and stanols effectively reduced LDL-C by approximately 10% at 2g/day, with effects maintained over >6 months, though sterols may show reduced efficacy over time compared to stanols. However, studies on surrogate cardiovascular risk markers did not demonstrate favorable effects.
population_specificity: Free-living populations and participants in multiparametric interventional studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of dietary phytosterol supplementation on blood triglyceride concentrations, including therapeutic response variability, potential mechanisms, and genetic factors influencing efficacy.
results_summary: Phytosterol supplementation resulted in a variable triglyceride-lowering response (0.8-28%), with hypertriglyceridemic individuals showing greater reductions (11-28%) than those with normal levels (0.8-7%). Genetic factors like apolipoprotein E polymorphisms may influence responsiveness, and multiple mechanisms (e.g., reduced intestinal fatty acid absorption, modulation of hepatic lipogenesis) likely contribute to the effect.
population_specificity: Hypertriglyceridemic individuals (>1.7 mmol/L) and subjects with normal plasma triglyceride concentrations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to confirm the efficacy of 1.8 g/day esterified plant sterols/stanols in improving lipid profiles in individuals with hypercholesterolemia, replicating prior findings in an independent sample.
results_summary: The study found significant placebo-adjusted reductions in LDL cholesterol (-4.3%), non-HDL cholesterol (-4.1%), and total cholesterol (-3.5%), but no significant effects on triglycerides or HDL cholesterol. These results support the efficacy of the supplement in reducing atherogenic lipid levels.
population_specificity: Men and women with primary hypercholesterolemia (LDL cholesterol ≥ 130 and <220 mg/dL).
effective_dosage: 1.8 g/day esterified plant sterols and stanols.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of phytosterol supplementation on risk factors of coronary artery disease in metabolic syndrome patients consuming a Westernized diet.
results_summary: Phytosterol supplementation significantly reduced total cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, small and dense LDL levels, apoB, and triglycerides compared to the control group, with no changes in HDL cholesterol, apoA1, glucose, C-reactive protein, fibrinogen, or blood pressure.
population_specificity: 108 patients with metabolic syndrome on a Westernized diet.
effective_dosage: 4 g phytosterols per day via 2 plant sterol-enriched yogurt mini drinks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a phytochemical-enhanced diet (including phytosterols) on lipid profiles and cardiovascular risk markers in individuals with metabolic syndrome and elevated LDL-C.
results_summary: The phytochemical-enhanced diet (PED) group showed significant improvements in lipid profiles (total cholesterol, LDL-C, non-HDL-C, etc.) compared to the control group, with more participants achieving LDL-C levels below 160 mg/dL.
population_specificity: Adults with metabolic syndrome and LDL-C ≥ 160 mg/dL.
effective_dosage: Not specified (medical food containing soy protein and plant sterols, plus a nutraceutical).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piceatannol promotes osteogenic differentiation in human periodontal ligament fibroblasts (HPLFs) and the role of MAPK activation in this process.
results_summary: Piceatannol increased alkaline phosphatase activity and osteogenic differentiation markers (Osteocalcin and Runx2), but these effects were reduced by MAPK inhibitors, suggesting piceatannol promotes osteogenic differentiation via MAPK activation.
population_specificity: Human periodontal ligament fibroblasts (HPLFs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of Piceatannol, among other natural polyphenolic compounds, on key cancer-related processes such as apoptosis, proliferation, migration, invasion, angiogenesis, and autophagy.
results_summary: Piceatannol, a metabolite of resveratrol, demonstrated anticancer properties, particularly in modulating autophagy, similar to resveratrol's effects on apoptosis, proliferation, migration, and invasion in gastric cancer cells.
population_specificity: Gastric cancer cells (in vitro or animal models, not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the neuroprotective effects of piceatannol (PCT) in preventing neuronal injury from cerebral ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) and investigate its mechanism via the USP14/GPX4 signaling axis.
results_summary: PCT significantly enhanced cell viability, reduced lipid peroxidation, and inhibited neuronal ferroptosis by modulating key proteins (GPX4, ACSL4, FPN1, Ferritin). In vivo, PCT reduced brain tissue damage and improved cognitive dysfunction in mice.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to cerebral I/R injury and neuronal cells exposed to oxygen-glucose deprivation/reoxygenation (OGD/R).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify natural XOD inhibitors for hyperuricemia treatment and elucidate the molecular mechanism of piceatannol-mediated XOD inhibition.
results_summary: Piceatannol exhibited strong XOD inhibitory activity (IC50 = 8.80 ± 0.05 μM) and favorable binding stability through hydrogen bonding and hydrophobic interactions, inducing conformational changes in XOD. ADME predictions suggested desirable drug-like properties and safety characteristics.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piceatannol and its analogues could inhibit β-lactamase activity, disrupt biofilms, suppress toxins, and enhance antibiotic efficacy against S. aureus.
results_summary: Piceatannol and its analogues inhibited β-lactamase, reduced antibiotic MICs, enhanced bactericidal effects, suppressed biofilm formation, and neutralized α-hemolysin toxicity. It also improved survival rates in infected Galleria mellonella and reduced tissue damage.
population_specificity: S. aureus (USA300 strain) and Galleria mellonella (wax moth larvae) models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of sterol-fortified orange juice or orange juice beverage on pro-inflammatory cytokines and PAI-1 in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: Sterol-fortified orange juice and beverage significantly reduced IL-1b and IL-6 levels, while unfortified versions had no effect on inflammatory biomarkers or PAI-1 activity.
population_specificity: 144 healthy human volunteers (72 in each study).
effective_dosage: 1g/240 ml juice or beverage, twice daily (total 2g sterols/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the pharmacodynamic effects and molecular mechanisms of Piceatannol-3'-O-β-D-glucopyranoside (QZZG) in treating acute ischemic stroke (AIS).
results_summary: QZZG improved histopathologic features, reduced infarct volume and neurologic deficits, and protected neurons by regulating glutamate and its receptors, inhibiting neuroexcitotoxicity and ferroptosis via the NMDAR/NRF2/BACH1/ACSL4 pathway.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro models based on the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanism by which Piceatannol (PIC) attenuates oxidative damage to sperm during cryopreservation.
results_summary: PIC at 5.0 μmol/L significantly improved sperm motility, viability, and plasma membrane integrity while reducing ROS levels. It modulated oxidative stress via the Keap1-Nrf2/ARE pathway, but these benefits were reversed with an Nrf2 inhibitor.
population_specificity: Semen samples (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piceatannol inhibits lactate transport via MCT1 and MCT4 and its effects on cancer cell viability and migration.
results_summary: Piceatannol effectively inhibited MCT1 at low micromolar concentrations, with less impact on MCT4, and significantly reduced cancer cell viability and migration. The study highlights Piceatannol as a cost-effective, low-toxicity compound for targeting MCTs in cancer.
population_specificity: Cells expressing MCT1 or MCT4 (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Low micromolar concentrations (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer effects of piceatannol on human neuroblastoma cells, focusing on cytotoxicity, apoptosis, autophagy, and related gene expression.
results_summary: Piceatannol exhibited cytotoxic effects, reduced colony formation, induced apoptosis and autophagy, inhibited cell invasion, decreased mitochondrial membrane potential, and increased ROS levels in neuroblastoma cells. It also upregulated key genes associated with apoptosis and autophagy.
population_specificity: Human neuroblastoma cells (SH-SY5Y cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism by which piceatannol (PIC) inhibits proliferation and migration of uveal melanoma (UM) cells, focusing on pyroptosis and the TREM2/caspase 3/GSDME pathway.
results_summary: PIC effectively inhibited UM cell proliferation and migration, enhanced apoptosis, increased oxidative stress, and suppressed inflammatory responses. It activated the caspase 3/GSDME pyroptosis pathway via TREM2 upregulation, and these effects were replicated in a mouse model.
population_specificity: Uveal melanoma (UM) cell lines (C918 and Mum-2b) and a mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how Piceatannol (PIC) affects hyaluronic acid biosynthesis and the role of SIRT1 in this process.
results_summary: PIC increased HAS2 expression (promoting hyaluronic acid synthesis) and decreased HYAL2 expression (reducing hyaluronic acid degradation) in human dermal fibroblasts. PIC also enhanced SIRT1 expression, and SIRT1 inhibition mitigated PIC's effects, suggesting SIRT1 mediates PIC's promotion of hyaluronic acid synthesis.
population_specificity: Human dermal fibroblast Hs68 cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Piceatannol (PCN) in reducing inflammation, apoptosis, and cellular damage in the hippocampus following experimental subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) in rats.
results_summary: PCN administration reduced apoptosis, cellular edema, and pyknosis in the hippocampus after SAH and significantly decreased the expression levels of inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-6, NF-κB) and the pro-apoptotic protein Bax.
population_specificity: Wistar Albino male rats (200-300 g; 7-8 weeks old)
effective_dosage: 30 mg/kg, administered intraperitoneally at 1 hour after SAH

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined anticancer efficacy of piceatannol and low-dose shikonin in GLO I-dependent cancer cell lines.
results_summary: Combined treatment with piceatannol and shikonin synergistically reduced cell viability, enhanced apoptosis, and increased methylglyoxal accumulation in HL-60 and NCI-H522 cancer cells compared to single-agent treatment, without altering PKM1, PKM2, or GLO I protein expression.
population_specificity: HL-60 human myeloid leukemia cells and NCI-H522 human non-small-cell lung cancer cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review Piceatannol's chemistry, mechanism of action, and therapeutic potential for preventing and treating various human diseases.
results_summary: Piceatannol exhibits broad beneficial effects, including anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and anticancer properties, with higher antioxidant activity than resveratrol, but its bioavailability is comparatively lower.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (not specified human population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if piceatannol (PIC), alone or combined with vitamin D, could protect against bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis by modulating HDAC2, HDAC4, TGF-β, PI3K/AKT signaling, and antioxidant status.
results_summary: PIC, alone or combined with vitamin D, significantly improved lung histopathology, downregulated HDAC2, HDAC4, and TGF-β, inhibited PI3K/AKT signaling, reduced ECM deposition, and enhanced antioxidant capacity. The combination showed synergistic effects superior to monotherapy.
population_specificity: Adult male albino rats with bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis.
effective_dosage: 15 mg/kg/day (oral) for PIC; 0.5 μg/kg/day (intraperitoneal) for vitamin D.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential protective effects of piceatannol on colon cancer in rats, focusing on antioxidant and apoptotic pathways and histopathological changes.
results_summary: Piceatannol significantly ameliorated oxidative damage, apoptosis, and histopathological changes induced by PHZ, upregulated mir-145, P53, and PDCD-4, and downregulated PI3K, AKT, c-Myc, CK-20, SOX-2, OCT-4, and NanoG.
population_specificity: Male albino rats with PHZ-induced colon cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Piceatannol and related hydroxylated stilbenes on Alzheimer's disease-associated factors in vitro and in animal models.
results_summary: Piceatannol showed the highest activity in scavenging free radicals, inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, and preventing amyloid-β aggregation. In scopolamine-induced mice, Piceatannol improved learning behavior, and RHA and isoRHA stimulated neurite outgrowth in cell models.
population_specificity: Scopolamine-induced ICR mice and SH-SY5Y cell models.
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg for mice, 10 μM for cell models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-influenza A virus (IAV) activities and mechanisms of Piceatannol (PIC) in vitro and in vivo to assess its potential as a novel plant-derived anti-IAV drug.
results_summary: PIC inhibited the multiplication of H1N1 and H3N2 viruses, blocked H5N1 pseudovirus infection with low toxicity, and disrupted IAV particles by targeting the viral envelope. Oral therapy with PIC improved survival and reduced viral titers in IAV-infected mice.
population_specificity: In vitro studies used viral assays, and in vivo studies used a mouse pneumonia model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piceatannol (PCT) provides neuroprotective effects by attenuating JNK3 downstream signaling and mitochondrial apoptosis in a rat model of global ischemic injury.
results_summary: PCT improved motor and memory function, increased cerebral blood flow, down-regulated caspase signaling, and up-regulated nitric oxide synthase expression. It also inhibited JNK3 phosphorylation and mitochondrial apoptosis, demonstrating neuroprotective effects.
population_specificity: Rat model of global ischemic injury

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cytoprotective effects of piceatannol on hydrogen peroxide-induced PC-12 cell damage and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Piceatannol pre-treatment significantly reduced H2O2-induced PC-12 cell death, improved mitochondrial function, and inhibited autophagy via the SIRT3 pathway, but these protective effects were abolished by SIRT3 inhibition or autophagy activation.
population_specificity: Pheochromocytoma-12 (PC-12) cells (a rat adrenal medulla cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the preventive effect of piceatannol on glutamate-induced neurodegeneration via mitochondrial rescue in Parkinson's disease models.
results_summary: Piceatannol prevented glutamate-induced apoptosis, reduced mitochondrial ROS accumulation, promoted mitochondrial biogenesis, and protected dopaminergic neurons in both PC12 cells and C. elegans models.
population_specificity: PC12 cell line and three Caenorhabditis elegans strains.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piceatannol (PIC) could protect against benzo[a]pyrene (B[a]P)-induced DNA damage and oxidative stress in human colon epithelial cells, potentially preventing colorectal cancer (CRC).
results_summary: PIC effectively inhibited B[a]P-induced CYP1B1 protein expression, alleviated DNA damage, enhanced DNA repair proteins, reduced oxidative stress by increasing glutathione and scavenging ROS, and activated the Nrf2 pathway to upregulate detoxification and antioxidative enzymes.
population_specificity: NCM460 normal human colon epithelial cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Piceatannol (PIC) as a SIRT1 activator in reducing Brucella abortus infection in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: PIC reduced the uptake of Brucella in RAW264.7 cells and decreased intracellular survival of Salmonella. In mice, PIC augmented Brucella resistance and favored a Th2 immune response while reducing serum proinflammatory cytokine production.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 cells (in vitro) and mice (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the renoprotective effects of Piceatannol-3'-O-β-d-glucopyranoside (PG) in experimental nephropathy, focusing on podocyte injury and inflammatory pathways.
results_summary: PG improved adriamycin-induced podocyte injury, attenuated nephropathy, and reduced inflammatory cytokine levels. It also modulated the HMGB1/TLR4/NF-κB signaling pathway, suggesting a potential mechanism for its renoprotective effects.
population_specificity: SD rats with adriamycin-induced nephropathy and in vitro MPC-5 podocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether piceatannol-3'-O-β-D glucopyranoside (PG) could mitigate colistin-induced neurotoxicity and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: PG significantly reduced colistin-induced neuronal apoptosis, oxidative stress, and mitochondrial damage by activating the NRF2/HO-1 pathway, while also suppressing autophagy levels in nerve cells.
population_specificity: N2a cells (in vitro) and mice (in vivo)
study_duration: 24 hours (in vitro), duration in vivo not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of piceatannol-3'-O-β-D-glucopyranoside (PG) on cognitive impairment and its underlying mechanisms in scopolamine-induced mice.
results_summary: PG administration significantly improved memory impairments in mice, reduced levels of Ach, AchE, and inflammatory factors, and increased antioxidants. It also down-regulated MMP3, MMP9, and BACE1 mRNA expressions, suggesting potential benefits for mild cognitive impairment.
population_specificity: Scopolamine-induced cognitive impairment mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective mechanism of Piceatannol (PCT) against age-related hearing loss (ARHL) by examining its effects on inner ear hair cell damage and inflammation.
results_summary: PCT protected mice from inflammatory aging-induced hearing loss and reduced deficits in inner hair cells and spiral ganglion. In vitro, PCT decreased reactive oxygen species, inflammation-associated proteins, and pyroptosis, suggesting protection via the Caspase-11-GSDMD pathway.
population_specificity: Mice and HEI-OC-1 cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Piceatannol (PIC) combined with cisplatin has a synergistic effect on N, N-nitrosodiethylamine (DEN)-induced hepatocellular cancer (HCC) in rats.
results_summary: PIC and/or cisplatin significantly improved liver function, modulated Nrf2 gene expression and antioxidant enzymes, reduced tissue MDA, TNF-α, NF-κB levels, NQO1 activity, and caspase-3 activities, showing a synergistic anticancer effect.
population_specificity: Rats with DEN-induced hepatocellular cancer (HCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate piceatannol as a potential Beclin-1 targeting agonist and assess its efficacy as an antitumor agent against gastric cancer.
results_summary: Piceatannol inhibited gastric cancer cell proliferation, increased autophagic flux, and directly interacted with Beclin-1, reducing its phosphorylation activity. It also showed synergistic antitumor effects with everolimus in xenograft models.
population_specificity: Human gastric cancer cell lines and xenograft models.
interactions: Synergistic effect with everolimus (mTOR inhibitor) noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of piceatannol (PIC) in protecting renal tubular epithelial cells (HK-2) from high glucose (HG)-induced injury and to identify its potential mechanism of action via carbonic anhydrase 2 (CA2).
results_summary: PIC at high concentration reversed HG-induced cell injury by improving viability, reducing apoptosis, and modulating oxidative stress markers and AKT pathway-related proteins. CA2 was identified as a target of PIC, and its inhibition by acetazolamide (ACZ) negated PIC's protective effects.
population_specificity: Renal tubular epithelial cells (HK-2) in vitro.
effective_dosage: High and low concentrations (specific amounts not provided).
interactions: Acetazolamide (ACZ) reversed PIC's effects, indicating a potential interaction with CA2 inhibitors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether piceatannol induces apoptosis and exhibits anticancer activity in pancreatic cancer cell lines (PANC-1 and MIA PaCa-2).
results_summary: Piceatannol reduced cell viability, induced apoptosis, increased ROS production, decreased mitochondrial membrane potential, and inhibited colony formation, invasion, and migration in pancreatic cancer cells. It also altered the expression of apoptosis-related genes and proteins.
population_specificity: Pancreatic cancer cell lines (PANC-1 and MIA PaCa-2).
effective_dosage: IC50: 60 µM in PANC-1 and 90 µM in MIA PaCa-2 at 48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effect and mechanism of Piceatannol (PCT) on myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury, particularly its role in regulating iron metabolism to prevent ferroptosis.
results_summary: PCT increased Nrf-2 expression, reduced intracellular ferrous ions and lipid peroxidation products, upregulated Ferroportin1 (FPN1), and inhibited transferrin receptor-1 (TfR-1), thereby protecting against ferroptosis-induced cardiomyocyte damage following ischemia-reperfusion injury.
population_specificity: Mice and cardiomyocytes (in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-Toxoplasma gondii activity of piceatannol, both in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: Piceatannol potently inhibited T. gondii proliferation (98.9% inhibition at 100 μM) and showed therapeutic effects in infected mice (15 mg/kg), though it did not affect parasite invasion. Abnormalities in parasite cell division were observed.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice infected with T. gondii (RH strain) and in vitro parasite cultures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piceatannol enhances oxaliplatin-induced immunogenic cell death (ICD) and anticancer immune response by promoting autophagy and endoplasmic reticulum stress.
results_summary: Piceatannol enhanced oxaliplatin-induced release of DAMPs (ATP, calreticulin, HMGB1), promoted autophagy via TFEB/TFE3 activation, and improved anticancer effects in immunocompetent mice. The combination of piceatannol with oxaliplatin showed potential as an ICD enhancer in cancer immunotherapy.
population_specificity: Immunocompetent mice (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piceatannol could protect against oxidative injury and collagen synthesis in pulmonary fibrosis (PF) via the JAK2/STAT3 signaling pathway.
results_summary: Piceatannol significantly improved pulmonary function, reduced oxidative injury, and decreased collagen synthesis in BLM-induced PF mice and TGF-β-stimulated lung fibroblasts by inhibiting JAK2/STAT3 activation. The effects were reversed by the JAK2 agonist coumermycin A1.
population_specificity: Mice (8-10 weeks old) and murine primary lung fibroblasts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effect of piceatannol on salivary gland degeneration induced by isoproterenol in rats.
results_summary: Piceatannol reduced proliferative activity in salivary glands, with higher doses restoring activity to control levels, demonstrating a protective effect against ISO-induced degeneration.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats
effective_dosage: 20 mg/kg and 40 mg/kg daily, administered intraperitoneally
study_duration: 10 days (3 days pre-ISO and 7 days with ISO)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of piceatannol on selenite-induced cataracts in rats and explore its antioxidant therapeutic effects.
results_summary: Piceatannol significantly reduced lens opacity, improved histopathological damage, downregulated oxidative damage markers (MDA), and upregulated antioxidant enzyme activity (GSH, catalase, SOD) in rats. In vitro, it restored cell viability and reduced apoptosis under H2O2-induced injury.
population_specificity: Eight-day-old Sprague-Dawley rat pups and SRA01/04 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piceatannol (PIC) exhibits anti-fibrotic effects in bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis in mice and to explore its mechanisms of action.
results_summary: PIC significantly reduced collagen deposition and myofibroblast accumulation in bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis. It promoted autophagy by inhibiting the TGF-β1-Smad3/ERK/P38 signaling pathway, leading to fewer activated myofibroblasts in vitro and in vivo.
population_specificity: Mice with bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis and fibroblast cell lines (NIH-3T3 and HFL1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the drug-drug interaction (DDI) between Ginkgo Amillaria oral solution (GAO) and Piceatannol-3'-O-β-D-glucopyranoside for injection (PGI) in the context of cerebrovascular disease treatment.
results_summary: The study found that GAO significantly increased the AUC and T1/2 of PGI while decreasing its CL, indicating a pharmacokinetic interaction. PGI was primarily metabolized by UGT1A9, and GAO inhibited UGT1A9 and UGT2B7, leading to altered PGI metabolism.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo models used).
interactions: GAO significantly interacts with PGI by inhibiting its metabolism via UGT1A9 and UGT2B7.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of piceatannol in reducing cancer-associated lipolysis and cachexia-induced weight loss.
results_summary: Piceatannol reduced cancer-associated lipolysis by at least 50% in vitro and protected tumor-bearing mice against weight loss in early stages of cachexia by preserving adipose tissue, though it had no effect on survival.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 adipocytes in vitro and C26 colon carcinoma-bearing mice in vivo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piceatannol (PIC) could target the interaction between M2-like tumor-associated macrophages (M2-TAMs) and cancer cells to inhibit colorectal cancer (CRC) progression and metastasis.
results_summary: Piceatannol effectively reduced aggressive features and stemness in SW480 cancer cells by inhibiting M2-like macrophage polarization and disrupting the TGF-β1 feedback loop between macrophages and cancer cells. In vivo, PIC significantly suppressed tumor growth and lung metastasis, likely through inhibition of TGF-β receptor type-1 (TGF-βR1).
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer (CRC) models (in vitro SW480 cells and in vivo mouse xenografts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the protective effects of Piceatannol (PIC) against indomethacin-induced gastric injury in rats and elucidate its underlying mechanisms of action.
results_summary: PIC at 5 and 10 mg/kg doses effectively reduced ulcer and lesion indices, acid production, and histological damage caused by indomethacin. It also reduced oxidative stress, inflammation, and enhanced mucin, PGE2, and angiogenesis markers.
population_specificity: Rat model (not specified if male/female or age).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Piceatannol (PIC) on rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and identify its molecular targets, focusing on inflammatory response and apoptosis in RA-fibroblast-like synoviocytes (FLSs).
results_summary: PIC significantly reduced proinflammatory cytokines (PGE2, IL-6, IL-1β), downregulated MMP-3 and MMP-13, and inhibited NF-κB and MAPK signaling pathways. In vivo, PIC decreased arthritis scores and improved cartilage health in a rat collagen-induced arthritis model.
population_specificity: Collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) rat model and RA-fibroblast-like synoviocytes (FLSs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hepatoprotective effect of piceatannol against CCl4-induced liver fibrosis in mice.
results_summary: Piceatannol significantly improved hepatic function, reduced collagen deposition, and suppressed fibrotic markers in CCl4-treated mice. It also alleviated oxidative damage by increasing glutathione levels and catalase activity.
population_specificity: Mice with CCl4-induced hepatic fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piceatannol (PIC) could mitigate glucolipotoxicity-induced endothelial barrier dysfunction and identify its mechanisms of action.
results_summary: PIC treatment improved endothelial cell motility, adhesion, and migration under high glucose/lipid conditions, stabilized cytoskeletal proteins, preserved vascular junction integrity, and reduced NF-κB/p65 activation and ROS levels.
population_specificity: Endothelial cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of piceatannol on atopic dermatitis (AD) using animal and cell line models.
results_summary: Piceatannol reduced AD-like symptoms in mice, including skin thickness, dermatitis score, and immune cell infiltration, and downregulated inflammatory markers. It also decreased JAK-STAT phosphorylation in HaCaT cells, suggesting a potential mechanism of action.
population_specificity: NC/Nga mice with induced AD-like symptoms and TNFα/IFNγ-induced HaCaT cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piceatannol (PIC) could protect against cisplatin-induced peripheral neuropathy in rats.
results_summary: PIC reversed cisplatin-induced behavioral, biochemical, and histological alterations, including thermal hypoalgesia, reduced locomotor activity, and nerve damage, while also decreasing serum neurotensin and platinum accumulation in the sciatic nerve.
population_specificity: Rats with cisplatin-induced peripheral neuropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piceatannol induces autophagy and/or apoptosis in HL-60 human acute myeloid leukemia cells and whether these cells can develop resistance to its toxicity.
results_summary: Piceatannol at 14 µM induced caspase-dependent apoptosis in HL-60 cells but did not trigger autophagy. The study also found that HL-60 cells could acquire resistance to piceatannol toxicity, likely through MRP1-related mechanisms.
population_specificity: HL-60 human acute myeloid leukemia cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role and mechanism of Piceatannol (PIC) in attenuating sepsis-induced myocardial dysfunction (SIMD) by targeting the JAK2/STAT3 pathway.
results_summary: PIC significantly improved cardiac function, reduced myocardial loss, and suppressed inflammatory responses in both septic mice and LPS-stimulated H9C2 cardiomyocytes by inhibiting the JAK2/STAT3 pathway. The cardioprotective effects of PIC were partially blocked by a JAK2 inhibitor (AG490), confirming its mechanism of action.
population_specificity: Septic mice and LPS-stimulated H9C2 cardiomyocytes (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cytoprotective effects of piceatannol on ROS-mediated PC-12 cell damage and mitochondrial dysfunction.
results_summary: Piceatannol significantly reduced oxidative damage, apoptosis, and mitochondrial dysfunction in PC-12 cells, while enhancing mitochondrial respiration. These effects were mediated via the SIRT3/FOXO3a pathway, as inhibition of SIRT3 abolished the protective effects.
population_specificity: PC-12 cells (a rat neuronal cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anti-adipogenic effects of piceatannol and resveratrol in human visceral adipose-derived stem cells (vASCs).
results_summary: Piceatannol showed a higher anti-adipogenic effect than resveratrol at 20 μM, significantly inhibiting lipid accumulation and reducing the expression of adipogenic markers (C/EBPα, PPARγ, aP2) at both mRNA and protein levels.
population_specificity: Human visceral adipose-derived stem cells (vASCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piceatannol (PIC) could mitigate oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis in hepatic and renal tissues induced by gamma-radiation or reserpine, focusing on mitochondrial biogenesis pathways.
results_summary: PIC significantly reduced oxidative stress markers (lipid peroxides, NO) and increased antioxidant enzyme activities (SOD, CAT, GSH-PX, GR). It also lowered inflammatory (TNF-α, IL-6) and apoptotic markers (cytochrome c, caspase-3), improved mitochondrial function (ATP, complex I activity), and restored tissue architecture in irradiated or reserpine-treated rats.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to gamma-radiation (6 Gy) or reserpine (1 g/kg BW).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piceatannol exerts anticancer effects on osteosarcoma cells via regulation of miRNA expression, particularly focusing on the miR-21/PTEN/AKT signaling pathway.
results_summary: Piceatannol inhibited osteosarcoma cell proliferation in a dose-dependent manner and induced apoptosis, primarily by downregulating miR-21 and blocking the PTEN/AKT signaling pathway. Restoration of miR-21 weakened Piceatannol's therapeutic effects, confirming its role in the anticancer mechanism.
population_specificity: Human osteosarcoma (OS) cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of piceatannol in preventing and/or treating non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) by examining its effects on fat accumulation, lipogenesis, fatty acid uptake, and oxidation.
results_summary: Piceatannol significantly reduced fat accumulation, suppressed lipogenesis and fatty acid uptake by decreasing SREBP1 and CD36, and promoted fatty acid oxidation by increasing FXR, PPARα, and CPT1α in steatosis-induced HepG2 cells. It also suppressed oxidative stress and inhibited phosphorylation of JNK and ERK1/2.
population_specificity: Steatosis-induced HepG2 hepatocytes (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether piceatannol (PT) could reduce statin resistance and tolerance by inhibiting PCSK9 expression via p300 inhibitory activity.
results_summary: PT reduced statin-induced PCSK9 expression, stabilized LDLR, and lowered cellular cholesterol levels by inhibiting p300 HAT activity. Co-administration of PT with simvastatin further reduced plasma LDL-C levels and stabilized hepatic LDLR in a hypercholesterolemia mouse model.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (in vitro) and high-fat diet-induced hypercholesterolemia mice (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of Piceatannol (Pic) on cerebral ischemia/reperfusion injury (CIRI) in mice, focusing on the Sirt1/FoxO1 pathway.
results_summary: Pic improved neurological function, reduced oxidative stress and apoptosis markers, and activated the Sirt1/FoxO1 pathway in a mouse model of CIRI. High-dose Pic did not increase non-enzymatic antioxidant levels, and the neuroprotective effects were blocked when the Sirt1/FoxO1 pathway was inhibited.
population_specificity: 8-week-old C57BL/6 mice with induced cerebral ischemia/reperfusion injury.
effective_dosage: Low dose (10 mg/kg/day) and high dose (20 mg/kg/day), administered orally once daily.
study_duration: 7 days (1 hour post-CIRI and then daily for 6 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Piceatannol (PIC) on liver health in piglets experiencing oxidative stress induced by diquat (DQ).
results_summary: PIC supplementation reduced oxidative damage by decreasing malondialdehyde (MDA) levels, increasing reduced glutathione (GSH), enhancing mitochondrial function (complex I, II, III, and V activities), boosting ATP production, and inhibiting liver cell apoptosis.
population_specificity: Weaned male piglets (Duroc × [Landrace × Yorkshire]).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of piceatannol (PIC) on the proliferation and apoptosis of bladder cancer cell line EJ and explore the underlying mechanism.
results_summary: PIC inhibited the proliferation of EJ cells in a concentration- and time-dependent manner, blocked cells in G0/G1 phase, and enhanced apoptosis. It upregulated PTEN protein expression and downregulated Akt protein phosphorylation.
population_specificity: Bladder cancer cell line EJ (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect and mechanisms of Piceatannol (PIC) on lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-induced acute lung injury (ALI) in mice.
results_summary: PIC significantly reduced lung edema, histopathological damage, inflammation markers, and TLR4/NF-κB pathway activation while improving air-blood barrier integrity in LPS-induced ALI.
population_specificity: Mice with LPS-induced acute lung injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms of Piceatannol (PIC) in prostate cancer cell lines and assess the effects of PIC-rich yellow passion fruit extract (PFE) on prostate cancer growth in a TRAMP mouse model.
results_summary: PIC reduced prostate cancer cell viability, induced cell cycle arrest and apoptosis, and modulated key proteins (p53, p21, cyclin D1, cdk4). PFE treatment delayed disease progression in TRAMP mice, reducing preneoplastic lesions.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer cell lines (PC-3, 22Rv1, LNCaP, VCaP) and TRAMP mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the kinetics and inhibition mechanism of piceatannol on α-glucosidase, a target for type 2 diabetes mellitus treatment.
results_summary: Piceatannol exhibited strong non-competitive inhibition of α-glucosidase, binding with high affinity to induce conformational changes that block substrate entry, reducing enzyme activity. Computational studies validated the binding site outside the catalytic region, suggesting a novel target for developing α-glucosidase inhibitors.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the suppressive effects of piceatannol on hCMV infection and its underlying mechanisms in human diploid fibroblast WI-38 cells.
results_summary: Piceatannol prevented lytic changes induced by hCMV, suppressed viral protein expression and DNA replication, and reduced cellular senescence markers like SA-β-Gal activity and ROS production. It also attenuated hCMV-induced elevation of p16INK4a, suggesting a novel anti-hCMV mechanism.
population_specificity: Human diploid fibroblast WI-38 cells infected with hCMV Towne strain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Piceatannol in inhibiting osteosarcoma cell proliferation and inducing apoptosis, focusing on its regulation of the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway.
results_summary: Piceatannol (40 and 80 μmol/L) suppressed osteosarcoma cell activity and proliferation, induced apoptosis, and inhibited the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway. These effects were reversed by the pathway activator 740Y-P, and PIC also reduced tumor volume and weight in xenograft models.
population_specificity: Human osteosarcoma cells and nude mice xenograft models.
effective_dosage: 20, 40, 80 μmol/L (in vitro); intraperitoneal injection (in vivo, dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review Piceatannol's anticancer properties, including its source, chemistry, and molecular mechanisms involved in tumor regression.
results_summary: Preclinical studies indicate Piceatannol has potential to prevent or impede growth of various cancers (brain, breast, cervical, colon, liver, lung, prostate, skin). The review supports its use as an anticancer and chemopreventive agent.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (not specified if human or animal models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether piceatannol (PT) could protect against cadmium-induced testicular dysfunction in rats by examining its effects on oxidative stress, steroidogenesis, and spermatogenesis.
results_summary: PT treatment significantly alleviated cadmium-induced testicular dysfunction, improving sperm quality, steroidogenic markers, oxidative stress, and Nrf2-Keap1 signaling pathway regulation compared to cadmium-only treated rats.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether PFSE and its stilbene derivatives, including piceatannol, inhibit cancer cell proliferation via human glyoxalase I (GLO I).
results_summary: PFSE and its stilbenes inhibited GLO I activity and suppressed cancer cell proliferation more effectively in NCI-H522 cells (high GLO I expression) than in HCT116 cells (low GLO I expression), suggesting a potential novel anticancer strategy.
population_specificity: Human cancer cell lines (NCI-H522 and HCT116).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Piceatannol, alone or combined with resveratrol, could upregulate PD-L1 in cancer cells to enhance tumor visibility and improve responsiveness to PD-L1 blockade therapy.
results_summary: The study found that Piceatannol, at supra-pharmacological doses, upregulated PD-L1 in cancer cells, potentially sensitizing low PD-L1-expressing tumors to immune detection and eradication when combined with PD-L1 blockade therapy. This "SEE" strategy may expand patient selection criteria for improved treatment responsiveness.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (in vitro or preclinical models, exact population not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and mechanisms of Piceatannol (PIC) on osteoclast formation and bone resorption.
results_summary: PIC strongly inhibited osteoclast formation and bone resorption in a dose-dependent manner, suppressed key signaling pathways (MAPK, NF-κB, AKT), and promoted apoptosis of mature osteoclasts via caspase-3 expression.
population_specificity: Murine macrophage-derived osteoclast lineage cells (RAW264.7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piceatannol (PIC) protects against diabetic cardiomyopathy (DCM) by reducing inflammation, oxidative stress, and apoptosis in cardiac cells.
results_summary: PIC improved cell viability, reduced apoptosis, and attenuated inflammation and oxidative stress in high glucose-induced H9C2 cells and diabetic rats. It also improved cardiac function and reduced fibrosis in diabetic rats by activating the Nrf2/HO-1 pathway.
population_specificity: High glucose-induced H9C2 cardiac myoblasts and streptozotocin (STZ)-induced diabetic rats.
effective_dosage: 5 mg/kg and 10 mg/kg (oral administration in rats).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effect and molecular mechanism of piceatannol on hydrogen peroxide-induced retinal pigment epithelium cell damage.
results_summary: Piceatannol significantly inhibited H2O2-induced cell death and ROS generation, reduced apoptosis markers, and activated the Nrf2 signaling pathway, suggesting potential benefits for age-related macular degeneration. The cytoprotective effects were mediated via the PI3K/Akt pathway.
population_specificity: ARPE-19 (retinal pigment epithelium) cells in vitro

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism by which piceatannol exerts anti-atherosclerotic effects, specifically focusing on the miR-200a/Nrf2/GSDMD signaling pathway in macrophages.
results_summary: Piceatannol reduced lipid storage and pyroptosis in macrophages by inhibiting caspase1, GSDMD, IL-18, IL-1β, and NLRP3 expression, mediated through the miR-200a/Nrf2 pathway. Silencing miR-200a or Nrf2 reversed these effects, confirming their role in piceatannol's anti-atherosclerotic activity.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 cells (a murine macrophage cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Piceatannol (PIC) and resveratrol (RSV) on inflammation, oxidative stress, and sirtuin regulation in high-fat diet-fed mice.
results_summary: PIC improved glycemic control by enhancing insulin signaling and sirtuin activity, while RSV reduced proinflammatory markers and increased antioxidant enzyme levels. Both compounds lowered hepatic tumor necrosis factor-alpha, but had minimal effects on oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice, 20 weeks old, fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms of piceatannol's nephroprotective effects against cisplatin-induced kidney toxicity in rats.
results_summary: Piceatannol reversed cisplatin-induced kidney damage markers, reduced oxidative stress and inflammation, and suppressed apoptosis by modulating Nrf2/HO-1 signaling and inhibiting inflammatory and apoptotic pathways.
population_specificity: Rats with cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether piceatannol induces autophagy and apoptosis in MOLT-4 human leukemia cells.
results_summary: Piceatannol activated autophagy and induced apoptosis in MOLT-4 cells, evidenced by molecular markers like LC3-II protein increase and caspase-3 activation. However, prolonged exposure reduced its toxic effects, suggesting potential resistance development.
population_specificity: MOLT-4 human leukemia cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify microorganisms capable of converting resveratrol to piceatannol via regioselective hydroxylation and assess their efficiency in production.
results_summary: The study isolated two bacterial strains (Ensifer sp. KSH1 and Arthrobacter sp. KSH3) that efficiently hydroxylated resveratrol to piceatannol without by-products, achieving production levels of 3.6 mM and 2.6 mM, respectively. The hydroxylation activity was induced by 4-hydroxyphenylacetic acid, and cloning of hpaBC homologs into E. coli conferred resveratrol-hydroxylating activity.
population_specificity: Microbial cultures (Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria)
effective_dosage: Not specified (production levels: 3.6 mM and 2.6 mM)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the anti-cancer activities of piceatannol-3-O-β-D-glucopyranoside (PG), focusing on its effects on proliferation, metastasis, and angiogenesis in endothelial and malignant cancer cells.
results_summary: PG did not affect cell proliferation at concentrations up to 100 μM but significantly suppressed metastatic ability, MMP-9 activity, and angiogenesis in HT1080 and HUVEC cells, as well as in an in ovo chick chorioallantoic membrane assay.
population_specificity: Human fibrosarcoma (HT1080) cells and human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the bioavailability of piceatannol (PIC) and investigate its impact on nuclear p65 and HIF-1α in experimental colitis.
results_summary: Albumin nano-encapsulation of PIC enhanced its anti-inflammatory potential and improved its ability to modulate inflammation-related biomolecular pathways, suggesting a promising therapeutic option for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
population_specificity: Mice with dextran sulphate sodium-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piceatannol, alone or in combination with resveratrol, modulates PD-L1 expression in breast and colorectal cancer cells and affects tumor cell survival.
results_summary: Piceatannol alone induced PD-L1 expression and, when combined with resveratrol, synergistically upregulated PD-L1 in certain cancer cell lines, particularly Cal51 TNBC and SW620 colon cancer cells. The combined treatment also reduced tumor cell survival by increasing DNA damage markers, inducing caspase 3 cleavage, and causing G1-to-S cell cycle arrest.
population_specificity: Breast (Cal51 triple-negative) and colorectal (SW620) cancer cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piceatannol exhibits antiadipogenic and antilipogenic effects in human preadipocytes, particularly in the context of obesity-related metabolic complications.
results_summary: Piceatannol significantly reduced lipid synthesis/accumulation in both murine and human adipocytes, inhibited glucose transport, and decreased expression of key lipogenic markers (PPARγ, FAS, and GLUT4), regardless of the differentiation stage. These findings suggest potential clinical applications for obesity treatment.
population_specificity: Human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSC) derived from adipose tissues of lean and obese individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piceatannol could mitigate methylglyoxal (MG)-induced cytotoxicity in MC3T3-E1 osteoblastic cells, potentially offering therapeutic benefits for diabetic osteopathy.
results_summary: Piceatannol restored cell viability, reduced lactate dehydrogenase release, enhanced glyoxalase I activity and glutathione levels, and mitigated inflammatory cytokines, reactive oxygen species, mitochondrial dysfunction, endoplasmic reticulum stress, and autophagy induced by MG.
population_specificity: MC3T3-E1 osteoblastic cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of piceatannol on d-gal-induced aging in mice, focusing on behavioral and neurological outcomes.
results_summary: Piceatannol improved motor activity, spatial learning, and memory in aging mice, prevented neuronal loss, increased Nissl bodies, promoted cell proliferation, and activated the Nrf2 pathway, suggesting anti-aging effects.
population_specificity: Mice with d-gal-induced aging and natural aging mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Piceatannol's effects on antioxidant enzyme expression and its ability to mitigate oxidative stress in skeletal muscle cells.
results_summary: Piceatannol upregulated Ho-1 and Sod1 mRNA expression in a dose-dependent manner and was the most potent inducer of Ho-1 among tested compounds. It also reduced hydrogen peroxide-induced reactive oxygen species accumulation in C2C12 myotubes.
population_specificity: C2C12 skeletal muscle cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piceatannol, an arginase inhibitor, could improve vascular function in aged mice by enhancing nitric oxide production and reducing oxidative stress.
results_summary: Piceatannol administration reduced blood pressure, improved NO signaling, and enhanced vasorelaxation in aged mice by inhibiting arginase activity and stabilizing eNOS function. The treatment also attenuated contractile responses and improved vascular relaxation in aortic rings.
population_specificity: Aged mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piceatannol (Pic) could protect endothelial cells (ECs) against homocysteine (Hcy)-induced apoptosis, oxidative stress, and ER stress, with a focus on heme oxygenase-1 (HO-1) involvement.
results_summary: Piceatannol significantly inhibited Hcy-induced apoptosis, ROS generation, and ER stress in ECs by increasing HO-1 expression via Nrf2 activation. The protective effects of Pic were abolished when HO-1 was downregulated but mimicked by the HO-1 inducer hemin.
population_specificity: Human endothelial cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiandrogenic properties of piceatannol and its analogs in prostate cancer cell lines to assess their potential for chemoprevention.
results_summary: Piceatannol and its analogs inhibited androgen receptor activation in prostate cell lines, with significant effects observed at concentrations ≥1μM in LNCaP cells and ≤5μM in RWPE cells. The compounds also reduced prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels in LNCaP cells, with synthetic analogs showing the highest potency.
population_specificity: Human prostate cancer cell lines (LNCaP with T877A mutation and RWPE with wild-type androgen receptor).
effective_dosage: Concentrations ≥1μM for LNCaP cells and ≤5μM for RWPE cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of piceatannol on renal fibrosis and HDAC expression in a mouse model of unilateral ureteral obstruction (UUO).
results_summary: Piceatannol suppressed ECM protein deposition, collagen deposition, and reduced HDAC4 and HDAC5 protein expression in UUO kidneys, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for renal fibrosis via HDAC and p38-MAPK pathway modulation.
population_specificity: Mice with induced unilateral ureteral obstruction (UUO).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-obesity effects of Piceatannol in a high-fat diet-induced obese animal model.
results_summary: Piceatannol significantly reduced body weight, improved lipid profiles, decreased fat and liver weight, reduced adipocyte size, and altered gut microbiota composition in obese mice. It also modulated key metabolic proteins to decrease lipid accumulation.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piceatannol induces eryptosis (suicidal death of erythrocytes) and to explore the cellular mechanisms involved.
results_summary: Piceatannol (10-20 µM) significantly induced eryptosis in human erythrocytes, characterized by cell shrinkage, phosphatidylserine exposure, oxidative stress, and ceramide formation, but did not significantly increase cytosolic Ca2+ activity. The effects were partially dependent on Ca2+ and involved oxidative stress and ceramide.
population_specificity: Human erythrocytes (red blood cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the mechanisms of action, chemopreventive properties, and therapeutic potential of piceatannol against various types of human cancer.
results_summary: Piceatannol exhibits superior bioactivities compared to resveratrol, including inhibition of COX-1/2 and CSN-associated kinase, and demonstrates anticancer, antioxidant, and vasorelaxation effects. It shows potential in preventing hypercholesterolemia, arrhythmia, atherosclerosis, angiogenesis, and cardiovascular diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing data)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of piceatannol (PT) and pterostilbene (PS) on Aβ-induced apoptosis in PC12 cells to assess their potential protective role in Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: PT significantly reduced Aβ-induced apoptosis in PC12 cells by activating the PI3K/Akt/Bad signaling pathway and inhibiting downstream caspase-dependent pathways, while PS showed anti-apoptotic effects via a different PI3K/Akt mechanism. Both compounds increased cell viability and reduced oxidative stress.
population_specificity: PC12 cells (a rat neuronal cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if piceatannol has a preventive effect in the early stages of obesity-associated nephropathy in obese Zucker rats.
results_summary: Piceatannol-treated rats showed lower levels of urinary and renal Kim-1, a tendency for reduced renal fibrosis biomarkers and lipid peroxidation, and increased levels of polyunsaturated and omega-6 fatty acids, suggesting a mild renoprotective effect.
population_specificity: Obese Zucker rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piceatannol enhances the anticancer efficacy of gemcitabine in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) by investigating its synergistic effects on cytotoxicity and apoptosis.
results_summary: Piceatannol significantly enhanced gemcitabine's cytotoxic effects by lowering its IC50 value and increased late apoptosis by upregulating the proapoptotic protein Bak. The combination showed potential as a novel treatment strategy for NSCLC.
population_specificity: Human NSCLC A459 cell line (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of piceatannol and its metabolites on SIRT1 expression in THP-1 monocytic cells and compare them to resveratrol and its metabolites.
results_summary: Piceatannol, its metabolite isorhapontigenin, and passion fruit seed extract upregulated SIRT1 mRNA and protein expression, while resveratrol glucuronides and sulfate had no effect.
population_specificity: THP-1 monocytic cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of piceatannol in T cell activation, proliferation, and differentiation, focusing on its effects on adaptive immune responses.
results_summary: Piceatannol inhibited T cell activation markers (CD25, CD69), reduced cytokine production (IFNγ, IL-2, IL-17), suppressed T cell proliferation, and inhibited differentiation of naïve CD4 T cells into Th1, Th2, and Th17 cells, likely by blocking TcR signaling pathways (p-Erk, p-Akt, p-p38).
population_specificity: Murine splenic T cells from C57BL/6 mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral administration of piceatannol inhibits mammary tumor progression in mice.
results_summary: Piceatannol treatment reduced tumor growth, suppressed metastasis, and altered the tumor microenvironment by inhibiting key transcription factors, angiogenesis, lymphangiogenesis, and macrophage infiltration. It also increased apoptosis and reduced cytokine/chemokine levels.
population_specificity: Female BALB/c mice injected with 4T1 mammary carcinoma cells.
effective_dosage: 10- or 20-mg/kg body weight/day, administered by oral gavage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piceatannol enhances S1PR1 expression and migratory response in CLL cells, potentially aiding their egress from lymphoid tissues.
results_summary: Piceatannol, along with another Syk inhibitor (R406), was found to enhance S1PR1 expression in CLL cells and improve their migratory response toward S1P, suggesting a potential role in redistributing leukemic cells from tissues to circulation.
population_specificity: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) patients' leukemic cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the production of stilbenoids, including piceatannol, in peanut hairy root cultures using elicitors and assess their biological activity potential.
results_summary: The study found that co-treatment with methyl jasmonate and methyl-β-cyclodextrin significantly increased the yield of piceatannol and other stilbenoids in peanut hairy root cultures, suggesting a controlled and sustainable production method.
population_specificity: Peanut hairy root cultures (in vitro system)
effective_dosage: Not specified for piceatannol alone (elicitor treatment: 100 μM MeJA + 9 g/L CD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piceatannol and other resveratrol analogs inhibit CYP17A1, a key enzyme in androgen biosynthesis, as a potential mechanism for prostate cancer chemoprevention.
results_summary: Piceatannol significantly reduced secretion of DHEA, testosterone, and cortisol while increasing progesterone and aldosterone, indicating CYP17A1 inhibition. However, it was less effective than synthetic analogs like RSVTM in selectively targeting CYP17A1 activity.
population_specificity: Human adrenocortical carcinoma cells (H295R)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore Piceatannol's potential as a foetal Haemoglobin inducer for treating beta thalassaemia.
results_summary: The abstract suggests Piceatannol may reactivate foetal Haemoglobin, offering a cost-effective alternative therapy for beta thalassaemia, but specific results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with beta thalassaemia (theoretical or in vitro/in vivo study population not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential neuroprotective benefits of piceatannol, a stilbene, in preclinical models of neurological disorders.
results_summary: Initial preclinical research suggests piceatannol shows promise in regulating cellular pathways implicated in neurodegeneration, though clinical evidence remains limited compared to resveratrol. The abstract highlights the need for more comprehensive clinical studies to confirm its therapeutic effectiveness.
population_specificity: Preclinical animal models (specific species not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Pilates on the quality of life, pain, and mental health of pregnant women during pregnancy.
results_summary: Pilates improved perceived quality of life, sleep quality, and physical mobility in pregnant women, reduced lumbopelvic pain, and decreased anxiety and depression levels.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (499 participants, 268 in Pilates group, 231 in routine care group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of piceatannol on metabolic health in humans, focusing on glucose metabolism, insulin sensitivity, and other related parameters.
results_summary: Piceatannol supplementation in overweight men reduced serum insulin levels, HOMA-IR, blood pressure, and heart rate, but no beneficial effects were observed in non-overweight men or women of any BMI group. No significant effects were found on body weight, body composition, endothelial function, lipids, inflammation, oxidative stress, mood status, or Sirt1/p-AMPK expression in PBMNCs.
population_specificity: 39 subjects (10 overweight men, 9 overweight women, 10 non-overweight men, 10 non-overweight women) with BMI ≥ 25 or < 25.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of piceatannol and resveratrol on human adipose tissue, focusing on their influence on lipogenic and lipolytic activities, as well as their interactions with amine oxidases and quinone reductase.
results_summary: Piceatannol and resveratrol similarly inhibited monoamine oxidase (MAO) and hampered hydrogen peroxide detection, but only piceatannol inhibited basal and stimulated lipolysis at doses ≥100 μM. Piceatannol exhibited stronger antilipolytic action compared to resveratrol, suggesting potential benefits in limiting obesity-related lipotoxicity.
population_specificity: Subcutaneous adipose tissue samples from obese patients and mouse adipocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term and long-term effects of Mat Pilates and functional training on non-motor symptoms in people with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Mat Pilates improved cognition, depressive symptoms, anxiety, happiness, and loneliness in both short-term and long-term assessments, while the control group showed worsening in some symptoms.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease (35 participants) and a healthy reference group (11 participants).
study_duration: 12 weeks of intervention with a 6-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of Pilates practice on pregnancy-related pain, specifically pelvic, dorsal, and abdominal pain.
results_summary: Pilates was associated with reduced pelvic pain (OR 2.73) and abdominal pain (OR 5.24), but no significant effect was found for dorsal pain. The method showed promise for improving well-being during pregnancy.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (n = 107) in primary care settings.
study_duration: November 2018 to December 2019 (exact intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of an 8-week Pilates-based intervention versus a home exercise program on pain intensity, functional disability, and quality of life in patients with subacute low back pain.
results_summary: The Pilates group showed superior reductions in pain intensity and functional disability compared to the home exercise group, along with greater improvements in quality of life, particularly in physical function and general health. Both groups exhibited significant improvements, but Pilates was more effective in the subacute phase.
population_specificity: Patients with subacute low back pain (n=66).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of a 12-week Pilates exercise program on female sexual function, depression, and sexual experiences in premenopausal women with female sexual dysfunction (FSD).
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in Female Sexual Function Index (FSFI), Arizona Sexual Experiences Scale (ASEX), and Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) scores after 12 weeks of Pilates. The study group showed greater improvement in FSFI scores compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Sexually active premenopausal women with FSD (n=93).
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency/duration implied by the 12-week program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity versus low-intensity Pilates on pain, disability, and other outcomes in people with chronic non-specific low back pain.
results_summary: The study found negligible differences between high-intensity and low-intensity Pilates on pain, disability, and other outcomes at the end of the intervention and follow-up periods, though low-intensity Pilates had fewer adverse events.
population_specificity: 168 people aged 18-60 with chronic non-specific low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility, acceptability, and appropriateness of a mat-based Pilates program for seniors and investigate its effects on balance and core strength.
results_summary: The Pilates program was deemed appropriate, acceptable, and feasible by over 80% of participants, with over 80% reporting some health improvement. No significant balance improvements were observed, though individual gains were noted.
population_specificity: Males and females aged 65+ from retirement communities, English-speaking, and considered healthy.
effective_dosage: Mat-based Pilates program with up to 17 movements, difficulty and pace increased over 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether online Pilates training improves cognitive functions and dual-task performance in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: Online Pilates significantly improved cognitive functions (MoCA, TMT-B, ST) and dual-task performance during balance, walking, and functional mobility in PwMS compared to the control group. No improvements were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS)
effective_dosage: Pilates training via videoconference, three days per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of 24 weeks of mat Pilates on quality of life components in breast cancer survivors receiving hormone therapy.
results_summary: The Pilates group showed improvements in emotional aspects, social aspects, and mental health compared to the control group, as measured by SF-36, but no differences were found using breast cancer-specific questionnaires (EORT-30 and 23).
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors receiving hormone therapy (Tamoxifen or Aromatase Inhibitors).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an integrated motor learning clinical Pilates protocol could provide enduring improvements in motor skills (walking, balance, reaction time, cadence, and functional mobility) for patients with Parkinson's Disease compared to conventional physiotherapy.
