results_summary: The Pilates group showed significant improvements in gait, balance, reaction time, functional mobility, and cadence post-treatment, with some benefits (cadence and reaction time) persisting at the 3-month follow-up compared to conventional physiotherapy.
population_specificity: 32 patients with Parkinson's Disease (Hoehn & Yahr stages 2-3).
effective_dosage: 60 minutes of training twice a week, plus a home physiotherapy program 4 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a brief session of Clinical Pilates exercises could improve postural sway during single-leg squat, hamstrings flexibility, and lumbar flexion flexibility in adults with non-specific chronic low back pain.
results_summary: Participants showed statistically significant improvements in postural sway variables (vertical force variance, terminal knee flexion angle, squat duration), hamstrings flexibility, and lumbar flexion flexibility after the Pilates intervention. The exercises enabled deeper and faster squats while maintaining postural stability.
population_specificity: Forty adults with non-specific chronic low back pain.
effective_dosage: One to four Pilates exercises based on identified pain-free movements.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether protein supplementation enhances the effects of Pilates training on body composition, core muscle endurance, and joint flexibility in trained women.
results_summary: Ten weeks of Pilates training improved core muscle endurance, joint flexibility, and aspects of body composition, but protein supplementation did not enhance these adaptations. Body fat and hip circumference decreased, while lean mass, total water, and extracellular water increased.
population_specificity: Nineteen Pilates-trained women (aged 31 ± 9 years).
effective_dosage: 0.6 g of whey protein per kg body weight daily.

study_goal: To determine the effect of Pilates exercises on pain, endurance, quality-of-life, and disability in post-menopausal women with low back pain.
results_summary: Pilates showed significant improvements in pain, endurance, quality-of-life, and disability compared to conventional exercise. The study concluded that Pilates is superior to conventional physical therapy for alleviating non-specific low back pain in post-menopausal women.
population_specificity: Post-menopausal women with low back pain (n=128).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Mat Pilates on cardiovascular risk markers in postmenopausal women with single versus multiple cardiometabolic conditions.
results_summary: Mat Pilates reduced systolic blood pressure more in women with a single condition than those with multiple conditions, and triglycerides decreased only in the single-condition group. Glycated hemoglobin levels decreased in both groups, but no significant changes were observed in cholesterol or blood glucose levels.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with single or multiple cardiometabolic conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a home-based, self-managed Pilates intervention delivered via an exergame (MS-FIT) on balance, gait, cognitive performance, quality of life, and well-being in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a rigorous trial design but does not yet report results; data analysis and publication are expected in 2025. The abstract suggests Pilates may benefit physical, cognitive, and psychological symptoms in MS, but efficacy will be determined by future findings.
population_specificity: People with MS who have mild disability, low risk of falling, preserved cognitive functions, and low anxiety and depression.

study_goal: To evaluate the impact of eight weeks of Pilates on physical fitness and sleep quality in individuals with post-COVID-19 syndrome.
results_summary: The Pilates group showed significant improvements in the 6-min walk test distance, reduced post-exercise fatigue, and better sleep quality compared to the supervised physical exercise and control groups.
population_specificity: Individuals with post-COVID-19 syndrome (n=59).
effective_dosage: Twice a week for eight weeks (16 sessions total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pilates exercises, combined with dietary advice, could improve IBS symptoms, fatigue, anxiety, depression, and body weight in women with constipation-predominant IBS.
results_summary: The study found that Pilates exercises significantly improved IBS symptoms, bowel movement frequency, fatigue, anxiety, and depression compared to dietary advice alone, with moderate to large effect sizes. The Pilates group also showed a significant reduction in body weight, while the control group improved in all outcomes except weight.
population_specificity: Women aged 20-45 with constipation-predominant IBS (moderate to severe) diagnosed via Rome IV criteria.

study_goal: To analyze the short- and long-term effects of a 12-week Mat Pilates intervention on lower limb and hand grip strength in people with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Mat Pilates improved right-hand grip strength short-term and left leg extension/flexion strength short-term, with long-term benefits in right and left leg extension strength. Some improvements were also noted in the control group.
population_specificity: 23 people (61.7 ± 7.5 years) with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease.
effective_dosage: Not specified (Mat Pilates classes, frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the feasibility and potential effects of an online Pilates exercise program for people with mild to moderate disability due to multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found that the online Pilates program was feasible and showed significant improvements in waist circumference and the Sit to Stand Test, but no significant statistical differences in other measured outcomes despite some subjective improvements.
population_specificity: Women with mild to moderate multiple sclerosis (n=22).
effective_dosage: 45 minutes of Pilates exercise combined with 30 minutes of aerobic activity, twice a week.

study_goal: To assess the impact of a Physiotherapist-led Pilates Intervention on pain, physical function, and Health Related Quality of Life (HRQoL) in school-aged children with Generalised Joint Hypermobility (GJH).
results_summary: Two children showed reduced fatigue, one improved in muscle strength and HRQoL during the intervention phase. In the withdrawal phase, all children improved in strength for at least two muscle groups, and one showed reduced fatigue, pain, and improved postural control. No improvements were seen in pain or postural control during the intervention.
population_specificity: School-aged children (8-12 years) with Generalised Joint Hypermobility (GJH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of reformer Pilates exercises on cognitive functions in sedentary women.
results_summary: The reformer Pilates group showed significant improvement in cognitive functions (Stroop Test scores) compared to the control group, but no significant differences were found in right-left discrimination or sleep quality improvements between groups.
population_specificity: Sedentary women aged 24-50

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the effects of Pilates on postural misalignment by analyzing existing studies.
results_summary: Pilates showed moderate improvement in thoracic and lumbar angles in children and adolescents, with mixed evidence for other body segments. In adults, very low- to low-certainty evidence suggested benefits for shoulder angle, scoliosis, and lumbar lordosis.
population_specificity: Children, adolescents, and adults with postural misalignment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of Pilates on pain and mood scores among women with chronic pain in a substance use treatment facility.
results_summary: Pilates, combined with yoga, primarily improved mood, reduced anxiety, and enhanced self-image, with only 21.7% of participants reporting better pain management. Pain scores decreased modestly (0.19 units per week on a 0-10 scale), though pain control was not the primary benefit.
population_specificity: Women in residential rehabilitation for substance use disorder with chronic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Pilates versus Cognitive Functional Therapy in treating chronic neck pain.
results_summary: The study evaluated multiple outcome measures (pain, disability, functionality, etc.) but did not provide specific results in the abstract; it emphasized that the findings would determine whether Pilates outperforms Cognitive Functional Therapy.
population_specificity: 60 patients with chronic neck pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of online and face-to-face Mat Pilates training on health outcomes in adults with persistent long COVID symptoms, particularly fatigue.
results_summary: Face-to-face Mat Pilates training improved fatigue, functional capacity, and aerobic capacity, while no significant changes were observed in body composition or cardiometabolic markers. Online training showed no significant benefits compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Adults (52 ± 5.85 years) with persistent long COVID-related fatigue symptoms.
effective_dosage: Three times a week for 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pilates training could improve pulmonary function, respiratory muscle strength, and functional ability in burn patients with inhalation injury.
results_summary: The study found that Pilates training significantly improved pulmonary function (FVC, FEV1, PEFR, FEV1/FVC%), respiratory muscle strength (MIP, MEP), and functional capacity (6-MWT) compared to conventional physical therapy alone.
population_specificity: Burn patients with inhalation injury and deep partial-thickness flame burns covering 30-40% of total body surface area (TBSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Clinical Pilates Exercises (CPE) and Cervical Mobilization (CM) on pain, posture, and cervical range of motion in patients with Cervicogenic Headache (CHA).
results_summary: The study found that CPE, alone or combined with CM, improved pain parameters, posture, and cervical range of motion, with combined therapy showing the most significant benefits in deep neck flexor endurance.
population_specificity: 37 patients with Cervicogenic Headache (CHA).
effective_dosage: Clinical Pilates Exercises (CPE) applied 3 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of an 8-week Pilates intervention on a ballet dancer's strength, balance, and endurance.
results_summary: The study found increased torque levels, neuromuscular efficiency, endurance test performance, and improved body balance after the Pilates intervention.
population_specificity: A healthy 24-year-old ballet dancer with no prior Pilates experience.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of Pilates on common body postures, focusing on cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine alignment, as well as quality of life and pain.
results_summary: The review found that Pilates effectively improves body posture problems, with six of the 13 included studies rated as high quality or above. It suggests Pilates can serve as a beneficial complementary therapy for postural disorders.
population_specificity: 783 trial participants across 13 studies, primarily individuals with postural disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify optimal dose parameters of Pilates exercise for the rehabilitation of musculoskeletal conditions.
results_summary: The review found clinically relevant Pilates dosing parameters that improved outcomes for musculoskeletal disorders, with the most frequent duration being 8 weeks, 2-3 sessions per week, lasting 50-60 minutes. Chronic low back pain was the most studied condition.
population_specificity: Patients aged 20-60 years with musculoskeletal conditions.
effective_dosage: 2-3 sessions per week, 50-60 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a Pilates exercise program versus home-based exercises in individuals with chronic non-specific low back pain.
results_summary: Pilates showed significantly lower pain intensity, less disability, and higher health-related quality of life post-intervention compared to home-based exercises. At six-month follow-up, Pilates maintained a higher quality of life but no significant differences in pain and disability were observed.
population_specificity: 145 individuals aged 18-50 with chronic non-specific low back pain lasting ≥12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Pilates exercise on quality of life, functional capacity, cancer-related fatigue, depression, and salivary cortisol levels in colorectal cancer survivors.
results_summary: Pilates significantly improved quality of life, role functioning, functional capacity, and stool frequency in colorectal cancer survivors, but no significant changes were observed in cancer-related fatigue, depression, or salivary cortisol levels.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer survivors
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency implied as regular sessions over eight weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of mind-body cueing in Pilates on outcomes for individuals with chronic non-specific low back pain (CNSLBP), particularly focusing on pain, functional disability, and fear of movement.
results_summary: Both Pilates groups showed significant improvements in pain, functional ability, and kinesiophobia, but the mind-body cueing group had a statistically greater reduction in fear of movement compared to the non-cueing group. The findings suggest that incorporating mind-body cueing in Pilates may enhance therapeutic benefits, especially for patients with high movement-related fear.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-65 years with chronic non-specific low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding conventional treatment (CT) to clinical Pilates improved pain levels, physical condition, functional status, and psychosocial status in individuals with chronic neck pain.
results_summary: The study found that CT combined with Pilates was more effective than Pilates alone in reducing pain, disability, fear of movement, depression, and negative biopsychosocial status, while improving neck mobility, endurance, and quality of life.
population_specificity: Fifty women with chronic neck pain.
effective_dosage: Treatment was administered 3 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 60-minute and 30-minute Pilates programs on cervicothoracic alignment, muscular strength, and endurance in university students with upper-crossed syndrome (UCS).
results_summary: Both 60-minute and 30-minute Pilates programs significantly improved cervicothoracic alignment (CVA, HPA, HTA, KA) and shoulder muscular function (strength and endurance), with no significant differences between the two durations. The control group showed no improvements.
population_specificity: University students with upper-crossed syndrome (UCS).
effective_dosage: 60 minutes or 30 minutes per session, twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Pilates training with and without the Vibro-Swing system on balance, muscle strength, and proprioception in older adults.
results_summary: The experimental group (Pilates with Vibro-Swing) showed statistically significant improvements in balance, muscle strength, and wrist joint proprioception compared to the control group (regular Pilates). The improvements included gait velocity, cadence, functional reach, sit-to-stand performance, grip strength, and joint position sense.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age: 78.31±4.50 years)
effective_dosage: 40-50 minutes per session, twice a week

study_goal: To examine the effect of pregnancy Pilates-assisted birth preparation training on urinary incontinence during pregnancy and postpartum, as well as birth outcomes.
results_summary: Pilates reduced urinary incontinence severity, decreased pregnancy weight gain, increased vaginal birth rates, and shortened labor duration compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Nulliparous pregnant women at 28-30 weeks gestation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Pilates with photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) would enhance outcomes for patients with chronic nonspecific low back pain (CNLBP).
results_summary: The mat Pilates program reduced peak pain intensity, perceived disability, and pain catastrophizing, but PBMT provided no additional benefit. Neither Pilates alone nor combined with PBMT improved postural balance.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic nonspecific low back pain (CNLBP).
effective_dosage: 8-week mat Pilates program with PBMT (active or sham) applied before and after each session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Pilates and Neuromuscular Integrative Action (NIA) on physical fitness and psychological outcomes in sedentary women.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in BMI, physical fitness tests (6MWT, Sit and Reach, Static Plank), and quality of life (SF-36) in the Pilates group after 8 weeks of training. Between-group comparisons showed similar results for Pilates and NIA, suggesting NIA may be an alternative to Pilates.
population_specificity: Sedentary women aged 20-45 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a 12-week Mat Pilates intervention on quality of life, fatigue, and body image in head and neck cancer survivors compared to a usual care control group.
results_summary: The Mat Pilates group showed significant improvements in quality of life, body image, and fatigue compared to the control group, with statistically significant results across multiple subscales.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer survivors (n=30)
effective_dosage: Twice a week, one hour per session

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Pilates exercises, corrective exercises, and Alexander's technique on upper cross syndrome in adolescent girls.
results_summary: Pilates exercises did not show significant improvements in forward head angle, rounded shoulder, or kyphosis abnormalities, unlike corrective exercises and Alexander's technique, which demonstrated significant reductions in these measures.
population_specificity: 13 to 16-year-old female students diagnosed with upper cross syndrome.
effective_dosage: 60 minutes per session, three sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining cervical mobilization with clinical Pilates exercises improves pain, muscle stiffness, and blood flow in patients with cervicogenic headache.
results_summary: The study found that combining cervical mobilization with clinical Pilates exercises significantly reduced headache intensity and frequency, decreased muscle stiffness, and improved blood flow compared to cervical mobilization alone. The CM+CPE group showed better outcomes in headache intensity and sternocleidomastoid muscle stiffness.
population_specificity: 25 patients with cervicogenic headache.
effective_dosage: Clinical Pilates exercises were applied 3 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and functional benefits of a virtual, seated, group-based Pilates program in individuals with mild to severe multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found improvements in balance (Berg Balance Scale, statistically significant) and mobility (Timed 25-Foot Walk, Timed Up-and-Go), but no significant changes in physical activity or MS-related outcomes. Participants reported high satisfaction with the program.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild to severe multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a Pilates-based exercise program could reduce low back pain and improve spine muscle endurance in helicopter pilots of the Brazilian Air Force.
results_summary: The Pilates group showed significant reductions in low back pain and increased endurance of trunk extensors and lateral muscles after 12 weeks compared to the regular exercise group, though disability indexes did not change.
population_specificity: Helicopter pilots of the Brazilian Air Force with chronic low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of the Pilates stance on height, waist circumference, and interscapular distance compared to standard clinical stance guidelines.
results_summary: Pilates stance increased height by up to 2.7 cm, decreased waist circumference by up to 5.2 cm, and reduced interscapular distance by up to 14 mm, with greater effects observed after training and when measurements were taken by an expert.
population_specificity: 48 healthy females with a median age of 60 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute effects of Pilates exercises on flexibility and performance in practitioners of an extreme conditioning program (ECP).
results_summary: A single session of Pilates significantly improved flexibility (p < 0.001) and performance in one ECP movement (p < 0.001), while also reducing perceived effort.
population_specificity: Individuals practicing an extreme conditioning program (ECP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and safety of a short-term Pilates-based exercise program for improving upper limb motor coordination in people with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found the Pilates program feasible and safe, with 100% adherence and only mild muscle pain reported. Pre-post differences were observed for body bradykinesia and hypokinesia, but no significant changes were noted in handgrip strength, fine motor coordination, or upper limb functionality.
population_specificity: 15 patients with Parkinson's disease (4 women, 11 men; median age 66 years).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes/day, 3 days/week using Reformer, Cadillac, Chair, and Barrel equipment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the dose-response and health effects of an online Pilates-based program on weight control, low back pain severity, sleep disturbances, mood, and depression levels in pregnant women during pre-partum and post-partum periods.
results_summary: High-amount exercisers (270 min/week) prevented worsening of low back pain and sleep disturbances during pregnancy, while intermediate-amount exercisers (150 min/week) showed significant post-partum improvements in sleep and depression. Depression scores improved across all groups during pregnancy.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (low-risk, aged 18-45, single pregnancy, 20-28-week gestational age, normal BMI).
study_duration: Pre-partum and post-partum periods (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding a six-month Pilates program to a three-month pulmonary rehabilitation improved respiratory muscle strength, physical function, and other outcomes in individuals with COPD.
results_summary: The study found that Pilates significantly improved maximal inspiratory and expiratory pressure, resistance to exercise-induced fatigue, and balance at six and nine months, but no consistent improvements in lung function or general muscle strength were observed.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), specifically GOLD B classification.
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency/duration: six months of Pilates after initial three-month pulmonary rehabilitation).
study_duration: Nine months total (three months of pulmonary rehabilitation followed by six months of Pilates for the intervention group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Pilates versus gym ball exercises in reducing pain and menstrual distress among women with primary dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: Pilates exercises resulted in significantly lower pain scores (2.60 vs. 5.46) and menstrual distress (79.33 vs. 103.26) compared to gym ball exercises, with both groups showing notable post-test reductions (p ≤ 0.001). The study concluded that Pilates is an effective holistic approach for managing primary dysmenorrhea.
population_specificity: Young females aged 17-25 years with primary dysmenorrhea, excluding those with secondary dysmenorrhea, medical conditions, or medication use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of static stretching and Pilates stretching on the concentric muscle strength of the knee extensors and flexors.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between static stretching and Pilates stretching on muscle strength performance. Only the control group showed a minor intragroup improvement in knee flexor strength at 180°/s.
population_specificity: 102 trained young adults (33 static stretching, 34 Pilates stretching, 35 control).
effective_dosage: 3 sets x 30 seconds for each body region (knee extensors and flexors).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Pilates on hamstring flexibility and back pain in pre-adolescent girls compared to Eutony and Holistic Gymnastics.
results_summary: Pilates, along with the other interventions, significantly increased hamstring flexibility and reduced back pain complaints, with 37.50% of participants reporting pain post-intervention compared to 66.25% initially. Additionally, 25% of participants improved their backpack-carrying posture.
population_specificity: Pre-adolescent girls aged 10-13 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Pilates exercises on lumbo-pelvic alignment and functional outcomes in patients with non-specific low back pain (NSLBP).
results_summary: Pilates led to significant improvements in self-reported functional outcomes (RMDQ) but no significant changes in lumbo-pelvic alignment or lumbar ROM, except for a minor improvement in ROM for the active extension pattern group. No correlations were found between self-reported outcomes and alignment/ROM parameters.
population_specificity: 22 patients (7 male, 15 female) aged 20-65 with NSLBP, classified into flexion pattern (FP) or active extension pattern (EP) groups.
effective_dosage: 60-minute sessions, up to two sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of Reformer Pilates on vascular function in older adults.
results_summary: Reformer Pilates significantly improved brachial artery flow-mediated dilation (FMD) at all measured time points post-exercise and regulated blood pressure for approximately 60 minutes, though no significant differences were observed in blood pressure or mean arterial pressure between conditions.
population_specificity: Older adults (age: 65 ± 2.76 years, BMI: 23.42 ± 3.68 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 19 exercise postures for 60 minutes at a perceived exertion scale of 3.5-5.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding Pilates exercises to a physical therapy program improves balance, gross motor coordination, and quality of life in children with Down syndrome.
results_summary: Both groups improved, but the Pilates group showed significantly greater improvements in dynamic balance, gross motor coordination, and quality of life compared to the control group. The results were statistically significant (P < 0.0001).
population_specificity: Children with Down syndrome, aged 8-10 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of four months of Pilates training on sleep quality, aerobic capacity, and anaerobic power in premenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that Pilates significantly improved sleep quality (reduced insomnia and sleepiness scores), aerobic fitness, muscle strength, flexibility, balance, abdominal endurance, and quality of life subscales in premenopausal women.
population_specificity: Premenopausal women (experimental group n=40, control group n=13).
effective_dosage: At least three one-hour Pilates sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a twelve-week online Pilates program combined with a Mediterranean diet on body composition in obese females.
results_summary: The study found that the Pilates group showed significant reductions in fat mass percentage and increases in fat-free mass, appendicular skeletal muscle mass, and skeletal muscle mass compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Thirty-five obese females.
effective_dosage: Three times per week, 180 minutes per week (Pilates Matwork program).

study_goal: To analyze the effect of Pilates on quality of life, fatigue, and sleep quality in breast cancer patients undergoing hormone therapy.
results_summary: Pilates improved fatigue (time effect p=0.034), sleep quality (time effect p=0.025), and global health (time effect p=0.024) for all participants, with sustained benefits observed six months post-intervention.
population_specificity: 34 women with breast cancer undergoing adjuvant hormone therapy.
effective_dosage: 16 weeks of mat Pilates (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Pilates on static and dynamic postural balance in older women.
results_summary: Pilates significantly improved dynamic postural balance (measured by SPPB and TUG) but did not significantly improve static balance (measured by force platform), though most values decreased.
population_specificity: Women aged 60 years or older.
effective_dosage: 16 sessions, twice a week, lasting 50 minutes each.
study_duration: 8 weeks (assuming twice weekly sessions over 16 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Pilates on core muscle endurance (CS) and static trunk balance in individuals recovering from COVID-19.
results_summary: Pilates significantly improved core endurance and trunk balance in recovered COVID-19 patients, with notable improvements in most measured parameters, though no significant difference was found in ellipse area with open eyes between groups.
population_specificity: 145 university students aged 19-25 who had recovered from COVID-19.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Pilates-based core strengthening, plyometric-based muscle loading, and their combination on postural control, balance, and mobility in children with unilateral cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The combined Pilates and plyometric intervention showed significantly greater improvements in postural control, balance, and mobility compared to either intervention alone, with statistically significant results across multiple measures.
population_specificity: Children aged 12-18 years with unilateral cerebral palsy (n = 81).
effective_dosage: Twice per week for 12 weeks (equated for total sets/repetitions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of Pilates on spinal deformity and posture through a systematic review of existing studies.
results_summary: The review found that Pilates is effective in correcting spinal deformities and posture, improving quality of life, pain relief, function, and fitness. However, more research is needed to validate its use as a physical therapy for spinal deformity rehabilitation.
population_specificity: 643 participants across nine studies, focusing on individuals with spinal deformities or posture issues.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the literature on the effects of Pilates on depressive disorders.
results_summary: Pilates was found to be effective in improving depressive symptoms, especially compared to inactivity and when practiced for 8-16 weeks, with comparable effectiveness to aerobic exercise. The results suggest Pilates can be a reliable complementary treatment for depressive disorders, though more homogeneous studies are needed for generalizability.
population_specificity: People with depressive disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Pilates versus no Pilates on strength and physical posture in young soccer players undergoing continuous football training.
results_summary: The Pilates group showed significant improvements in muscle strength (p = 0.001) but no significant postural changes compared to the control group. Five weeks of mat Pilates was sufficient to increase lower limb muscle strength in young football players.
population_specificity: 15 soccer club members (ages not specified) with a training frequency of at least three times weekly.
effective_dosage: Fifteen sessions of mat Pilates (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to familiarize readers with Ramadan fasting practices and its implications on drug therapy, physiology, and disease pathology.
results_summary: The abstract highlights potential impacts of Ramadan fasting on body physiology, disease pathology, and drug pharmacokinetics/pharmacodynamics, emphasizing the role of healthcare professionals in ensuring safe fasting practices.
population_specificity: Muslims observing Ramadan fasting (general population, no specific subgroup mentioned).
interactions: Potential interactions with medications mentioned, but no specifics provided.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of SGLT2 inhibitors during Ramadan on hypoglycemia, glycemic control, and kidney function in high-risk type 2 diabetes patients treated with insulin.
results_summary: The study found minimal fasting interruption, significant improvement in glycemic control, and no significant change in kidney function after Ramadan. Hypoglycemia was predominantly reported during specific time slots in Ramadan compared to pre-Ramadan readings.
population_specificity: High-risk type 2 diabetes patients treated with insulin ± SGLT2 inhibitors who insisted on fasting during Ramadan.
study_duration: Duration of Ramadan (exact length not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of Ramadan fasting on blood pressure in hypertensive patients using diuretics compared to those not using diuretics.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in systolic and diastolic blood pressure during Ramadan fasting in patients using diuretics, while non-diuretic users showed insignificant changes. Thiazide-like diuretics were more effective than thiazide-type diuretics, though the difference was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 129 hypertensive patients (73 on diuretics, 56 not on diuretics).
study_duration: During and after Ramadan (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between Ramadan fasting and glycaemic parameters in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found significant reductions in fasting plasma glucose (FPG) across different treatment regimens, as well as decreases in HbA1c(%) and body mass index (BMI) in the multi-OAD group. Ramadan fasting was not associated with negative effects on post-prandial plasma glucose (PPG) or fructosamine levels.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of flexible glycemic targets during fasting and tighter targets during non-fasting hours in insulin-treated people with type 2 diabetes during Ramadan.
results_summary: The study found that flexible glycemic targets during the day and tighter targets at night allowed safe fasting with significant improvement in overall glycemic control (HbA1c and serum creatinine) and minimal major complications (0.6% hypoglycemia episodes, 30% hyperglycemia episodes, no hospitalizations).
population_specificity: 54 people with type 2 diabetes on split mixed insulin therapy, mean age 54.65 ± 9.32 years.
effective_dosage: Insulin doses adjusted before Ramadan (specific amounts not provided).
study_duration: Duration of Ramadan fasting (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the biochemical and clinical effects of Ramadan fasting on type 2 diabetes (T2D) patients, particularly focusing on hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis risks associated with antidiabetic medications.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in glycated hemoglobin and fasting plasma glucose levels post-Ramadan, along with notable variations in serum lipid profiles. Antidiabetic medications were linked to low serum lactate levels, though a minor dose-independent increase was observed.
population_specificity: 150 patients with type 2 diabetes.
interactions: Antidiabetic medications (e.g., metformin) were noted to influence serum lactate levels.
